I just did a report for my Acoustics class involving the sound power of rocket engines and how to suppress/direct that energy. Modern rocket engines vary in sound power level (depending on the thrust * exit velocity), but an average would be 145dB to 180dB (where the Saturn-V is the loudest on record @ 220dB). For comparison, a 1 megaton nuclear bomb creates about 257dB!

What caught my eye during the launch of the SN8 is the fact there are birds flying within a few hundred meters of the pad. Normally, this is close enough so that the acoustic energy is enough to kill a human being. I guess the 2nd stage of the Starship didn't produce enough energy to take down those birds? Not that I wanted the birds to die, but it caught my attention.

Why not ventilate the skirt around the raptor-engines?

It appears to me that it would make a venturi-effect when running at least one engine, thereby avoiding flames and heat to collect under the skirt when only running one or two engines. It could even help increase thrust in atmospheric conditions. And depending on the construction, it could even lighten the Starship slightly.

One question. Do you think the FTS triggered on impact? Going frame by frame at approximately 14:16 just as it impacts, there looks to be a sideways cloud coming out about where the charges are, just before the fireball starts at the base. Hard to spot, and could well just be the tanks failing from the imapct, but it would make sense it triggered to ensure no pressured tanks after the hard landing.

awesome job Tim!

I remembered my 3rd question!
#3 as SN8 fell back just before it flipped vertical, you could see that the frost line on the nose header tank was very thin, indicating to me that it was low on anything cryogenic. This leads me to think maybe the reason for low fuel pressure was lack of fuel. Maybe the tank switch over happened way too early or something in the micro G of freefalling back to earth allowed the fuel in the header tanks to backflow into the main tank(s). Wild assed speculation for sure, but based on the nearly non extant frost on the nose header tank it's the only data I can use that makes any sense.

on Mars it'll take 2 or 3 simultaneous burns to slow it down slow enough to land. but it might not have the fuel for that after such a long trip. we might as well park a few in orbit  or Mars to transfer fuel... if that makes sense. refuel before entry of mars.. cause one burn before landing will turn you into soup compressing those kind of G forces

I'm afraid the spherical header tank for the methane is not going to work. I suggest a cylindrical syringe arrangement. Or, baffles to impede the slosh. I'd like to see someone make a model in Blender of what the methane is probably doing in there after that high-g J-turn. If the tank is being pushed with gaseous methane from the main tank, that gas is just blending into the spinning mass of liquid, making the fuel mixture for the rockets ever more lean, with surges and bubbles. That's my visualization.

I'm kind of glad is blew up on landing, as there is so so much to learn from the data and videos such as this. Imagine it landing ok, and a few years later one blows up because of lessons not learned from SN8. So much easier and cheaper to implement changes at this stage of design.
Obviously the main issue was in the fuel delivery, but I've also noticed other things that needs tweaking. (just my opinion, I'm no rocket expert, but I do write a lot of software code)
1. Over flipped. I think it slightly over flipped, although this maybe partly due to thrust loss during the flip.
2. Flaps. Wouldnt it be better to have all the flaps to extend out once it was close to the vertical position as to help further stabilise it?
3. Power loss. Requires a critical maneuvers mode. During dangerous maneuvers, min/max power targets, min/max distance to the ground or other objects should be set, and the craft given automated decisions to keep within those parameters. eg. it can instantly pull fuel from other tanks or instantly ignite other engines to meet the minimum required demands in those critical moments, or even use the cold gas thrusters to help correct. This should be a feature that can be turned on/off, as features such as these have been known to crash crafts because of incorrect input data.
4. No landing legs. I believe the craft was still trying to stablise the flip and hadnt entered landing mode. Landing mode would have contained many preparations before landing/hitting the ground. Landing mode needs to be triggered when the craft detects its landing whether expected or unexpected.
Wow!! I don't think the general public yet appreciates what a quantum leap forward this spacecraft represents.

I had previously understood from some Spacex simulation video that the terminal velocity (in horizontal configuration) would be 35m/s, which is about 120Km/h.

13:29 Seems like mostly or only the precise control of the thrust vectoring was enough to get it into the vertical orientation. The lower wings could have been in full extended position to act as air brake to counter the rotational speed of the back end of the rocket but it seems like it wasn't necessary . The canards and lower wings did come into play or only minimally where as all the coordination of the firing upper thrusters, the movements of the canards and wings and the thrust vectoring of the engines was needed to orient it from a vertical to a horizontal position. Great job SpaceX.
In the future perhaps they can even give the canards and wings the ability to partially rotate and that way they can exert even more precious control over the rocket.

Most people will read or see one day about the first Mission to Moon and be like, heck, so what? They may even feel the same about Mars flights. It's not like the 70's when people gathered in front of the single TV set in the entire village(mine at least) to watch the first moon landing. It really feels like a decades old loose end that just happens to be closed now.

Interesting flames when engines shut down. . . Oxygen cut first, then methane. Reminds of learning about lighting acetylene torches. . . A before O or up you go. . .

In this case, it’s the reverse during shutdown. And we saw when not enough fuel got to the engine during the landing burn. . . The oxygen-rich flame essentially “ate the engine”. . .

Watching those fins in slow motion. . . Awesome control!
